  14. (*                                                                        *)
  15. (**************************************************************************)

  17. (** Pseudo-random number generators (PRNG).

  19.     With multiple domains, each domain has its own generator that evolves
  20.     independently of the generators of other domains.  When a domain is
  21.     created, its generator is initialized by splitting the state
  22.     of the generator associated with the parent domain.

  24.     In contrast, all threads within a domain share the same domain-local
  25.     generator.  Independent generators can be created with the {!Random.split}
  26.     function and used with the functions from the {!Random.State} module.
  27. *)

  29. (** {1 Basic functions} *)

  31. ‌val init : int -> unit
  32. (** Initialize the domain-local generator, using the argument as a seed.
  33.     The same seed will always yield the same sequence of numbers. *)

  35. ‌val full_init : int array -> unit
  36. (** Same as {!Random.init} but takes more data as seed. *)

  38. ‌val self_init : unit -> unit
  39. (** Initialize the domain-local generator with a random seed chosen
  40.     in a system-dependent way.  If [/dev/urandom] is available on the host
  41.     machine, it is used to provide a highly random initial seed.  Otherwise, a
  42.     less random seed is computed from system parameters (current time, process
  43.     IDs, domain-local state). *)

  45. ‌val bits : unit -> int
  46. (** Return 30 random bits in a nonnegative integer.
  47.     @before 5.0 used a different algorithm (affects all the following functions)
  48. *)

  50. ‌val int : int -> int
  51. (** [Random.int bound] returns a random integer between 0 (inclusive)
  52.      and [bound] (exclusive).  [bound] must be greater than 0 and less
  53.      than 2{^30}. *)

  55. ‌val full_int : int -> int
  56. (** [Random.full_int bound] returns a random integer between 0 (inclusive)
  57.      and [bound] (exclusive). [bound] may be any positive integer.

  59.      If [bound] is less than 2{^30}, [Random.full_int bound] is equal to
  60.      {!Random.int}[ bound]. If [bound] is greater than 2{^30} (on 64-bit systems
  61.      or non-standard environments, such as JavaScript), [Random.full_int]
  62.      returns a value, where {!Random.int} raises {!Stdlib.Invalid_argument}.

  64.     @since 4.13 *)

  66. ‌val int32 : Int32.t -> Int32.t
  67. (** [Random.int32 bound] returns a random integer between 0 (inclusive)
  68.      and [bound] (exclusive).  [bound] must be greater than 0. *)

  70. ‌val nativeint : Nativeint.t -> Nativeint.t
  71. (** [Random.nativeint bound] returns a random integer between 0 (inclusive)
  72.      and [bound] (exclusive).  [bound] must be greater than 0. *)

  74. ‌val int64 : Int64.t -> Int64.t
  75. (** [Random.int64 bound] returns a random integer between 0 (inclusive)
  76.      and [bound] (exclusive).  [bound] must be greater than 0. *)

  78. ‌val float : float -> float
  79. (** [Random.float bound] returns a random floating-point number
  80.    between 0 and [bound] (inclusive).  If [bound] is
  81.    negative, the result is negative or zero.  If [bound] is 0,
  82.    the result is 0. *)

  84. ‌val bool : unit -> bool
  85. (** [Random.bool ()] returns [true] or [false] with probability 0.5 each. *)

  87. ‌val bits32 : unit -> Int32.t
  88. (** [Random.bits32 ()] returns 32 random bits as an integer between
  89.     {!Int32.min_int} and {!Int32.max_int}.
  90.     @since 4.14 *)

  92. ‌val bits64 : unit -> Int64.t
  93. (** [Random.bits64 ()] returns 64 random bits as an integer between
  94.     {!Int64.min_int} and {!Int64.max_int}.
  95.     @since 4.14 *)

  97. ‌val nativebits : unit -> Nativeint.t
  98. (** [Random.nativebits ()] returns 32 or 64 random bits (depending on
  99.     the bit width of the platform) as an integer between
  100.     {!Nativeint.min_int} and {!Nativeint.max_int}.
  101.     @since 4.14 *)

  103. (** {1 Advanced functions} *)

  105. (** The functions from module {!State} manipulate the current state
  106.     of the random generator explicitly.
  107.     This allows using one or several deterministic PRNGs,
  108.     even in a multi-threaded program, without interference from
  109.     other parts of the program.
  110. *)

  112. module State : sig
  113.   type t
  114.   (** The type of PRNG states. *)

  116.   val make : int array -> t
  117.   (** Create a new state and initialize it with the given seed. *)

  119.   val make_self_init : unit -> t
  120.   (** Create a new state and initialize it with a random seed chosen
  121.       in a system-dependent way.
  122.       The seed is obtained as described in {!Random.self_init}. *)

  124.   val copy : t -> t
  125.   (** Return a copy of the given state. *)

  127.   val bits : t -> int
  128.   val int : t -> int -> int
  129.   val full_int : t -> int -> int
  130.   val int32 : t -> Int32.t -> Int32.t
  131.   val nativeint : t -> Nativeint.t -> Nativeint.t
  132.   val int64 : t -> Int64.t -> Int64.t
  133.   val float : t -> float -> float
  134.   val bool : t -> bool
  135.   val bits32 : t -> Int32.t
  136.   val bits64 : t -> Int64.t
  137.   val nativebits : t -> Nativeint.t
  138.   (** These functions are the same as the basic functions, except that they
  139.       use (and update) the given PRNG state instead of the default one.
  140.   *)

  142.   val split : t -> t
  143.   (** Draw a fresh PRNG state from the given PRNG state.
  144.       (The given PRNG state is modified.)
  145.       The new PRNG is statistically independent from the given PRNG.
  146.       Data can be drawn from both PRNGs, in any order, without risk of
  147.       correlation.  Both PRNGs can be split later, arbitrarily many times.
  148.       @since 5.0 *)

  150.   val to_binary_string : t -> string
  151.   (** Serializes the PRNG state into an immutable sequence of bytes.
  152.       See {!of_binary_string} for deserialization.

  154.       The [string] type is intended here for serialization only, the
  155.       encoding is not human-readable and may not be printable.

  157.       Note that the serialization format may differ across OCaml
  158.       versions.

  160.       @since 5.1
  161.   *)

  163.   val of_binary_string : string -> t
  164.   (** Deserializes a byte sequence obtained by calling
  165.       {!to_binary_string}. The resulting PRNG state will produce the
  166.       same random numbers as the state that was passed as input to
  167.       {!to_binary_string}.

  169.       @raise Failure if the input is not in the expected format.

  171.       Note that the serialization format may differ across OCaml
  172.       versions.

  174.       Unlike the functions provided by the {!Marshal} module, this
  175.       function either produces a valid state or fails cleanly with
  176.       a [Failure] exception. It can be safely used on user-provided,
  177.       untrusted inputs.

  179.       @since 5.1
  180.   *)
  181. end

  183. ‌val get_state : unit -> State.t
  184. (** [get_state()] returns a fresh copy of the current state of the
  185.     domain-local generator (which is used by the basic functions). *)

  187. ‌val set_state : State.t -> unit
  188. (** [set_state s] updates the current state of the domain-local
  189.     generator (which is used by the basic functions) by copying
  190.     the state [s] into it. *)

  192. ‌val split : unit -> State.t
  193. (** Draw a fresh PRNG state from the current state of the domain-local
  194.     generator used by the default functions.
  195.     (The state of the domain-local generator is modified.)
  196.     See {!Random.State.split}.
  197.     @since 5.0 *)
